comments.body: is it necessary for golint?

golint reported this: 
`pkg/api/testapi/testapi.go:325:9: if block ends with a return statement, so drop this else and outdent its block`
Which makes sense, right? If we have return in `if` itself, then there is no need of `else`. We can just keep the logic outside of else block.

The purpose is adding the admissionregistration group to testapi even if it's not specified in "KUBE_TEST_API". Otherwise when running test locally, pkg/api/serialization_test.go doesn't test the admissionregistration types.
If nobody uses this, don't add it.  We want less code to touch for each group you add, not more.

diffHunk:
@@ -1,1 +291,295 @@	Storage = Groups[storage.GroupName]
	ImagePolicy = Groups[imagepolicy.GroupName]
	Authorization = Groups[authorization.GroupName]
}

comments.body: It'd be nice to have a unit test somewhere that makes sure this parallel registration stays in sync.
This is ugly. I would prefer this and/or other packages providing APIs to use to do the testing without having to modify this package and register it globally. Way out of scope though.
This whole package should not exist, we should reuse the manager in apimachinery/registered. It's a big change though. @mml This is one of the refactoring changes I want to make.
Whoops, this is duplicated now.
Thanks! Missed this when rebasing.
@soltysh I think this means we only test the last version of a group. Could you leave a note in test-go.sh and test-integration.sh?
That is correct. I'll add it right away.
Comment? Should this be a method on Groups instead?
Thanks for dealing with this file. I think it needs some help in the future but I won't ask you do to that.
Yes it does :/. My work is just a tip of an iceberg we need to dig into to get multiple versions fully testable.

I missed this in @piosz's change-- can you move the following `if _, ok := Groups[extensions.GroupName]; !ok {` section above the batch & autoscaling setup code? otherwise, referencing the extensions group here may not do what we want.
ok

I think I might have missed where this is used and what it's for. These 3 values seem readily available. I would understand if this actually returned a ContentConfig, but it only gives you 3 easily gettable values used to build one.

It doesn't return a ContentConfig because of a circular dependency (an awkward one).  The intent was to ease initialization of the struct, especially for when we want to switch out the content type and codec together (to test protobuf and yaml and others)
Hmm.. To me, this use case suggest that perhaps content type should be part of the codec. Thoughts?

I wanted to keep codec small enough that it was just two methods - encode
and decode.  Mime type is definitely something that the person who returns
the codec knows - the struct returned there looks a lot like
ContentConfig.  We could potentially move a contentconfig like struct into
runtime - but then would we want to import it into our client config struct?

The other case I had today was with the streaming codec (which will be a
follow up pull after split codec lands) - it feels reasonable for Encoder
to know how return an io.Writer that does framing (for streaming protocols)
- having both an Encoder and StreamingEncoder seems incorrect.  The short
  term choice I made was to have Encoder support returning a streaming
  encoder as an optional interface, but this means that wrapping encoders
  (something we want to encourage) becomes harder.  An alternate choice would
  be to have the mechanism for getting codecs to also allow you to say "i
  want the streaming codec for this codec" by passing a codec back.

No need to add this. Struct literals are fine.
The two fields of TestGroup are private. When I construct the TestGroup using struct literals in my test the compiler complains.
Thank you for fixing this!
Recommend just VersionUnderTest-- store e.g. "core" and "v1" separately, not "core" and "core/v1".
I'm not too worried about calling the function frequently, but if you want to store all three I won't complain.
I recommend just putting a default value into it if it's empty?

We will default the test versions to the latest version of groups several lines below this.

It's better to do the defaulting in the current way. Imaging the env var only contains parts of the groups, e.g.,  KUBE_TEST_API=v1, where the test version of the experimental group is not specified, then we need to default the left groups one by one.
Clarify the exact format this is returned in. group/version or just version?
Oh, I see, this is just version. It's probably clear enough.

The bodies of these two ifs are exactly alike-- can we lose the if statements?

i.e., make this function's body just be:

``` go
        interfaces, err := latest.InterfacesFor(g.GroupAndVersion())
        if err != nil {
            panic(err)
        }
        return interfaces.Codec
```
The reason they stay separate now is that we have latest and explatest. It's on my TODO list to have a central `latest`.
Ah, I did not notice the difference, sorry! This is fine then, maybe you can add a TODO about fixing it when we have a central `latest`.
Same comment as for Codec.
Same comment as for Codec.
This line has to be first, right? Prefix always comes first?

The position seems correct. It's not the same prefix we discussed. Its name is confusing.

a usage:
https://github.com/kubernetes/kubernetes/blob/master/pkg/client/unversioned/namespaces_test.go#L173

Ah, I see. I guess it's really a custom verb then.
